I don’t think people realise how rare it is for an entrepreneur like Deepinder Goyal to answer everything and not dodge questions.

Most founders in India, when things are going well, they’ll talk.
When things are messy, they disappear.

PR takes over.
Statements come out.
And the person becomes a brand.

This episode with Deepinder wasn’t like that.

Whether you like him or hate him, whether you think he is right or wrong, that is on you to decide.

But one thing you can't deny is that this guy shows up.
And he answers.

He is setting a bar for all entrepreneurs, public leaders on how not to shy away from answering, even when times are turbulent.

He didn’t sell inspiration.
He talked like a guy who has been in the fire for too long.

He talked about getting bullied as a kid. Stammering. Feeling like an outsider.

Imposter syndrome even after building something massive.

And then we went where most founders never go:
Firing people.
Hurting people.
The ugly side of scale.
The stuff leaders pretend doesn’t happen.
 
He even talked about delivery partner conditions.
What the protocols are.
What needs to improve.
 
The part of the system nobody wants to look at because it ruins the dopamine of ordering.

Most people in his position would just not bother talking. But he opened up about anything we threw at him.

Is India actually doing well, or are we just being told that it is?

On one side, markets are up, consumption is rising, and Gen Z is spending like never before.

On the other, the rupee looks weak, global narratives are shifting, and India keeps getting pulled into conflicts that aren’t really ours.

In this episode, Saurabh Mukherjea, Author and Founder of Marcellus Investment Managers, breaks down what most people miss when they talk about the economy.

We talked about:

– How China still holds leverage
– Why AI won’t kill jobs in 2026
– Why restrictions on F&O were inevitable
– How mimetic desire is driving Gen Z spending and debt
– Why India becomes the scapegoat when global systems break
– And how people can still earn money when everything around them feels unstable

He also gave clarity on which narratives are real and which ones are being sold to us.

If you’re trying to make sense of where India is actually headed economically, socially, and politically, this conversation is for you.

Corporate Facts That Hurt More Than Breakups 💔😂
Fact 1:
People don’t leave companies.
Companies leave people unread.

Fact 2:
“Let’s have a quick call” has destroyed more peace than any heartbreak ever has.

Fact 3:
Your performance review depends more on your manager’s mood than your actual performance.

Fact 4:
You don’t need an alarm clock.
You have anxiety.

Fact 5:
90% of “urgent” tasks magically stop being urgent after 6 pm.

And the saddest fact?
You can go from “We are a family” to “Your access has been removed” in 0.2 seconds.

If you relate, come sit.
We cry on weekdays and revive on weekends.

Presenting my 2025 LinkedIn Wrapped:

Messages I replied to immediately: 2
Messages I replied to after 7 days with “Sorry, missed this”: 143
Messages I saw, ignored, and still lost sleep over: 89

Recruiters who said “Your profile is impressive, let’s connect”: 27
Recruiters who vanished after I replied: all 27

People who endorsed me for skills I don’t even have: 11
People I endorsed out of guilt: 11

Webinars I registered for: 52
Webinars I actually attended: 0
Webinars I left running just for the certificate: 8

Times I opened LinkedIn for motivation: 34
Times I left LinkedIn feeling useless: 34

Posts I wrote from the heart: 7
Posts that went viral: 0
Posts I wrote in anger at 2 AM that surprisingly went viral: 1

People who said “Let’s grab coffee sometime”: 19
Actual coffees grabbed: 0
Times I grabbed coffee alone while thinking about my life: 47

Times I said “Let’s connect offline”: 13
Times I meant it: … let’s skip this one.

Meetings that could’ve been an email: 96
Emails that could’ve been nothing: 41
“Quick sync?” messages that ruined my entire day: 57

LinkedIn Wrapped 2025 taught me only one thing:
We’re all pretending to have our life together,
and honestly… we deserve an award for acting.

For years, I chased every milestone.
 💼 Bigger title
 💰 Higher salary
 📈 Better company
 🏙️ Fancy city

But every time I achieved one, I felt... nothing.

Just a few days of excitement, followed by the same emptiness again.
Then one day, I asked myself -
“What if I stopped chasing and started living?”
So I did.

I stopped trying to “impress.”
Started learning slowly.
Started eating better.
Started walking without earphones.
Started saying “no.”
Started choosing peace over people.
And the irony?

The moment I stopped chasing success - it started finding me.
 Better work.
 Calmer mind.
 Real people.
 Healthier body.

Because when you stop running after what you think you want, life finally gives you what you actually need.

If you’ve been feeling exhausted lately - maybe it’s not burnout.
Maybe your soul just wants a break from pretending.

I sometimes hate how we only post "happy" moments here and I have always wanted to change it.

So, I am going to start with myself.

No, I didn't get a new job, cracked a new company, got 7 figure salaries etc.

I just want to normalize being "not delighted/excited" all the time.

We live in a world where everyone is “grateful”, “honoured”, and “thrilled”.
But rarely do you see - “tired”, “lost”, or “unsure”.

We all are humans, and we all feel things - not all days are good.

You know what’s truly rare on LinkedIn?
Someone saying: “I don’t have it figured out, but I’m still trying.”

So, here I am -

I am not doing great, have been fighting - 1 day at a time. I think I will get through it :)

There's nothing more motivational than being myself for me :)

Job hunting in India is not for the weak.

You’ll see a post that says “We’re urgently hiring!”
You apply in 30 seconds.
And they ghost you faster than your ex.

“Easy Apply” feels like Tinder.
You swipe, they ignore.
And somewhere, HR writes - “We’ll get back to you.”

You update your resume 47 times, change fonts, remove hobbies, add buzzwords like “team player”, “growth mindset”, and “Excel wizard”…
Still no reply.
Meanwhile on LinkedIn:
People with 2 connections and 0 experience write -
“I’m thrilled to announce I’ve joined Google.”
And you’re sitting there thinking -
Maybe I should be “thrilled” to announce that I’m still unemployed.

But here’s the truth:
You’re not lazy.
You’re not behind.
You’re just living in a country where “experience required: 3 years” comes in intern listings.
So hang in there.

Because one day, you’ll get that offer.
And your “We’re happy to have you onboard” email will feel like a national award.

Imagine being an heir to a BILLION-dollar empire and still being told: “Pehle CA bano, then we’ll think business”... at a time when degrees are casually dismissed as irrelevant.

I spent last night watching Kumar Mangalam Birla on KBC and honestly walked away with even deeper respect for the person behind the position.

Nobody talks enough about how EARNED, and not entitled his leadership actually is.

I mean we’re so quick to dismiss “Nepo/Legacy kids” assuming their lives are so “easy”!
Opportunities. Networks. Access. Shortcuts.

But even as a BIRLA heir, there was no free pass.

Education was non-negotiable.
He wasn’t allowed to enter the business without first building real grounding.

👉🏾 An MBA from London Business School.
👉🏾 A Chartered Accountant.
👉🏾 A CFA.

These are NOT titles that can be bought with money. 
Anyone who’s done CA knows the grind, the sacrifice, the discipline it demands.

And those values showed up when it mattered most. 

At 28, barely four years into his professional career, he unexpectedly lost his father.

And overnight, he was expected to take charge of a billion-dollar business and hold everything together... while grieving.

Fast forward to today… he didn’t just preserve the legacy … he TRANSFORMED it into $67 billion global conglomerate

But still my favourite part of the whole episode was his simplicity!!

Unlike many flamboyant billionaire industrialists, he’s always avoided media hype and stayed quietly authentic.

His daughter, Ananya Birla, even shared how he studied for three weeks before going on KBC 😂
He clearly didn’t need to. But that detail says everything about his character.

Nothing is too small.
You show up prepared. Always. 
Because that’s showing respect to a stage, an opportunity. 

Left the episode with a lot of respect and had fun watching.
Did any of you watch yet?

If you’re not living life on your own terms,
toh tum jee nahi rahe ho… bas zinda ho.

Kab tak logon ke standards pe jeeyoge?
“Log kya kahenge” - ye line sabse zyada logon ki life barbaad karti hai.
Kisi aur ke approval ke liye apna peace, apna asli self compromise kar dena…
that’s not success, that’s slavery.

Hum sabko chase karna sikhaya gaya — marks, jobs, promotions, perfect relationships.
But kisi ne yeh nahi sikhaya ke apni marzi se jeena bhi ek achievement hoti hai.

Society ke hisaab se chale toh sab kuch mil jaata hai -
Bas khud se milna chhoot jaata hai.

The world claps when you get promoted.
But no one claps when you heal.
No one celebrates when you choose peace over chaos.
No one sees when you finally stop proving yourself.

Who are these “4 log”?
Wahi log jo kal kisi aur ke life pe opinion denge.
Unka judgement temporary hai,
tumhaari journey permanent.

Toh apne hisaab se jeeyo.
Chahe kam ho, par apna ho.
Chahe simple ho, par sachcha ho.

Because real success is not about how many people are proud of you.
It’s about whether you are proud of the person you’ve become.

What if I’m average, don't have any "talent", and that’s the truth?

Then congratulations. You just got rid of the most dangerous excuse in the world.

That "talented" person you're looking at? 
They've been doing the thing for years while you were still wondering if you're gifted enough to start. 

They made a 1000 ugly attempts you never witnessed. 
They showed up on days they felt nothing, created garbage they were ashamed of, got rejected so many times they stopped counting. 

And then one day, they did something great, and you looked at it and said, "wow, natural talent." 

As if their whole journey didn't exist. As if they just woke up like that.

You want the universe to whisper "you're the chosen one" before you risk anything. 

But the universe doesn't do that. 
The universe rewards movement, not potential. 
It doesn't care if you're gifted. It only cares if you show up.

And here's the funniest part, average people built the world. 
The people running successful businesses, creating things that matter, most of them are terrifyingly ordinary. 

They weren't top of their class, didn't have rich parents or special connections. They just picked something and stuck with it longer than everyone else. 

The world isn't run by geniuses. 
It's run by regular people who didn't quit.

Being average and knowing it is a cheat code. 
You've got nothing to lose. No “talented” identity to protect.

You already know you're not special. 
You have no ego about being a natural. 

So you can just put your head down and work like that’s all you have got.

A relationship feels stable until one person gets more options than the other.

That’s when things quietly change.
 
More attention.
More validation.
More people who suddenly “get you.”

And without realising it, love slowly turns into comparison.

In this conversation with Dr Sarthak Dave, MD Psychiatrist, we spoke about how relationships end when status, money, or options change the power dynamic.

He explains how:

- “Trading up” is sometimes about insecurity
- The brain starts chasing dopamine over depth
- As people grow, they don’t always grow together
- Many marriages in India are built on conditioning, not choice
- Why people choose short-term pleasure over long-term stability

The problem isn’t wanting better.
The problem is not knowing what “better” actually means.

This conversation was about seeing patterns.

Why relationships feel different after success, after growth, or after new attention enters the picture.

How do I regain confidence when I know I've been lazy and inconsistent?

Confidence isn't some mood you can summon with affirmations in the mirror. 

Confidence is just your brain's prediction of what you'll do based on what you've done. 

And right now, your brain has proof that when you say you'll wake up early, you don't. 

When you say you'll start Monday, you won't. 
When you promise yourself, "this time will be different," it isn't. 

So why would your brain let you feel confident? 
It's trying to protect you from the embarrassment of believing yourself again.

So stop trying to regain confidence. 
That's not your job right now. 

Your job is simpler and way less glamorous, become someone you can trust again. 

Start stupid small. 
I mean, embarrassingly small. 
So small your brain can't argue with it. 

Don't promise you'll write a book. 
Promise you'll open the document. 

Don't promise you'll change your life. 
Promise you'll do one tiny thing and actually do it. 

It's boring. It's slow. 
But it's the only thing that actually works.

Let confidence show up on its own when you've earned it back.

It will. Faster than you think.

What if your “healthy” diet is the reason you’re bloated, anxious, and breaking out, and you don’t even know it?

According to Dimple Jangda, Lifestyle Medicine Advocate and author of Heal Your Gut, Mind & Emotions, most people aren’t eating bad food.
 
They’re eating the wrong food for their body type.
And mixing the wrong things together.

You’ll see people doing all the “right” things: raw salads, fruit bowls, lemon water, curd, smoothies, coffee for energy, and still feeling tired, moody, and inflamed.

Your body has a blueprint.
And if you keep eating against it, your body keeps reacting.

In this episode, she breaks down:

- Wrong food combinations 
- The gut–emotion connection 
- The 3 body types (Vata, Pitta, Kapha) 
- Why some foods should never be eaten raw 
- Common “healthy” habits that mess up digestion
- Practical way to read cravings, sensitivities, and the tongue chart
